content: Title IX of the Education Amendments of 1972 provides legal relief for victims of sexual abuse and harassment at educational institutions, prohibiting discrimination based on sex in programs receiving federal funding. Schools can be held liable for damages for a deliberately indifferent response to such incidents, including teacher-student and student-on-student harassment. Enforcement of Title IX can occur through private rights of action or administrative agencies like the Department of Education. Title IX enforces antidiscrimination mandates for schools receiving federal funding, covering all levels of education. Compliance is required for participation in federal student aid programs, with liability for sexual harassment instances. The text of Title IX does not explicitly mention sexual abuse or harassment, but the Department of Education has issued guidance on schools' responsibilities in addressing allegations of sexual harassment. Educational institutions have developed procedures to investigate and respond to such allegations, with recent proposed regulations that could change their responsibilities significantly. The proposed Title IX regulations would change educational institutions' responses to sexual harassment allegations. The report provides background on legal interpretations of Title IX, including court cases and agency enforcement. It also discusses constitutional challenges and examines how the proposed regulations would impact schools' compliance with Title IX. The report examines ED's proposed regulations regarding Title IX, which prohibits sex discrimination in educational programs receiving federal funding. However, the statute does not explicitly address private right of action for victims or define sexual harassment as unlawful discrimination.
